instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PPVCORE_CPU: What is PPVCORE_CPU? PPVCORE_CPU is an abbreviation of PPVCORE_S0_CPU. When you see someone type PPVCORE_CPU, assume they meant to type PPVCORE_S0_CPU..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Board had damage had minor damage around <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>. Came with no fan spin and no green light. Regained green light and fan spin but now have no GPUVCORE and also missing CPUVORE. I have already told customer about possible GPU problems in the future but they insist to try to repair. Im not great with CPU stuff so Im not really sure where to go from here. Thanks.

<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PWRGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0.050v
<SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PWRGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0V


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - Present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - Present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get voltage on all other coils, especially L7100?
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> for high level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

0V on coils including L7100.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PRGD</SIGNAL> = 2.610V


Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PRGD</SIGNAL> = 2.610V"
Some coils should have voltage then; others than CPU ones...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Im sorry I thought you just meant CPU stuff. 

L7630 - 1.057V
L7220 - 4.98V
L9560 - 1.509V
L9510 - 1.021V
L7330 - 1.502V

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> voltage, pins VCC, VDDA/B, EN, TON.
Check if <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> has correct value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have previously replaced  7400 and <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>.

VCC - 4.92V
VDD A/B - 4.95V
TON - .543V
EN - 2.606V

<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> - 90k

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground at L8920.
Post <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> voltage, pins 16, 22, 14, 29.

New version of Tiresias Killer can disable GPU for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MLB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
resistance to ground at L8920 - 10.6Ohm

<CHIP>U8900</CHIP>

16 - 4.43V
22 - 4.94V
14 - 12.58V
29 - 3.296V

Thanks


Should I try replacing <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and Fets?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and now have 1.1V on GPU Vcore.

So if I get <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> back then it should POST and turn to .9V?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did you get CPU VCORE voltage?
It should post if it drops from 1.1-1.2V to 0.8-0.9V aprox, after few seconds...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_CPU</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>
